Topic.Title: ARM's 64-bit architecture is "clean and elegant"

Message.Msg: They've already released quite a bit of info on the architecture... In fact, it seems quite logical the evolution. With the expansion to 64-bit, the register set was doubled... But most predication was lost due to control bits now dedicated to more registers From what I read, AMCC had influence as well as NVDA... Probably working with ARMH before NVDA... Also, what NVidia will bring to the table is their compilers. Gonna use fixed-length ISA to their advantage... NVidia's first 64-bit SOC, Stark, Project Denver cores... 2014 if on schedule...

Topic.Title: ARM's 64-bit architecture is "clean and elegant"

Topic.Title: TSMC has achieved 80% yields 28nm

Message.Msg: You mean here comes the FUD! There is more wrong with Snapdragon 28nm than yield. watch

Topic.Title: TSMC has achieved 80% yields 28nm

Message.Msg: The 80% yield by itself does not lower NVDA costs directly. This Yield refers to the wafer Fab yield ie - if you start 100 wafers you get 80 wafers out. Typical processes should yield well above 95%. However since TSMC is able to yield more - NVDA may be able to go to them for a lower wafer price. Another potential benefit is the actual product yields may go up because some wafer process problems had been improved on - but the correlation can be iffy - but everybody would at least get more wafers. The wafer yield + added capacity is certainly good news for T4 and may be even better news for T3 which may cost the same or a little lower to make in 28nm but would have much lower power consumption that's already pretty good at 40nm and higher performance to boot - 2GHz? All we need is LTE inside :)

Topic.Title: TSMC has achieved 80% yields 28nm

Message.Msg: - Too bad TSMC's revenues are tanking. And tanking badly, boys. Take a lookie. If you can handle a cold cruel dose of excess chip-making capacity, bloated inventories of semiconductor chips, desperate discounts to woo fab customers, and imploding fourth quarter sales. http://news.cens.com/cens/html/en/news/news_inner_40890.html TSMC and UMC Offer Discounts to Counter Offseason Effect Taipei, August 3, 2012 (CENS) — To boost capacity utilization, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) have reportedly decided to offer DISCOUNTS on 40 nm and other mainstream processing services and resume PRICE REDUCTIONS reductions due to low season, with the DISCONTS, effective from September, totaling 5%, and both chip foundries declining to comment. Institutional investors pointed out that the two leading contract IC makers enjoyed booming business in the first half, leaving clients no leeway for price negotiation. Due to low season effect, they will offer DISCOUNTS starting September, in compliance with the recent comment of Morris Chang, TSMC chairman, that contract IC orders will DROP in the fourth quarter as clients adjust HIGH INVENTORIES. In the second quarter, 40nm processing technology accounted for 28% of TSMC’s revenues, followed by 65nm technology at 26%, and 28 nm technology at 7%. The upcoming DISCOUNTS apply to 40 nm and 60 nm technologies, both for 12-inch wafers and accounting for 54% of TSMC’s revenue, with the move to boost order placement by clients to enhance capacity utilization and consolidate gross margin. Semiconductor equipment suppliers reveal that capacity utilizations of the two chip foundries have begun EASING OFF off from August. Although TSMC’s high-priced 28 nm products are still enjoying booming shipment, clients for 40 nm processing technology no longer have to line up for capacities due to UMC’s expansion. Industry insiders estimated that revenue of TSMC in the fourth quarter may DROP 8-10% sequentially and its overall capacity utilization rate may also TUMBLE to 80-85% in the fourth quarter, DOWN from the third quarter’s 95%. Capacity utilization rate of UMC may also DIP below 80% in the fourth quarter." The outlook is Grim, boys. Oh so grim. Semiconductor orders are drying up, capacity utilization is plunging, TSMC and UMC are both offering discounts to find customers willing to risk making more chips in the face of already high inventories. All resulting in declining revenues. It is good that Chairman Morris Chang is being honest with his shareholders, warning that TSMC's fourth quarter revenue may DROP 8-10% sequentially. Unlike Jen. Who owns entirely too much nvda stock to ever be that honest. -

Topic.Title: TSMC has achieved 80% yields 28nm

Message.Msg: You are blowing smoke. 95% final yield maybe (post package). 60-70% is great for initial yield (good die from wafer). So anything above that is magnificent. NVDA is paying for wafers, not yield. Improved yield is cash in NVDA's pocket. Side note: looks like the BEST douche bag has released the bot.

Topic.Title: TSMC has achieved 80% yields 28nm

Message.Msg: - Interesting right? It sure is. While the pumper boys are focusing on TSMC "only" making 20% scrap parts, they ignore the Inconvenient Truth that the semiconductor industry is in a Bad southward tail-spin, with fourth quarter revenues expected to plunge by 10% sequentially. Says TSMC's Chairman Morris Chang. -
